Preface
Welcome to Principles of Islamic Economics, an open-access textbook designed for undergraduate students, curious professionals, and anyone seeking a structured introduction to economic thought in the Islamic tradition.

title: Principles of Islamic Economics
text:
Why This Book?
Economics textbooks typically begin with scarcity and rational self-interest, then build an entire discipline on those foundations. But what if we started from different premises — stewardship rather than ownership, justice rather than efficiency, community welfare rather than individual utility maximization? That is the intellectual project of Islamic economics.
This book presents Islamic economics as a coherent alternative framework for understanding how societies organize production, distribution, and exchange. It is not a defense of Islamic finance products or a guide to Sharia-compliant investing. Rather, it asks: What does an economy look like when its foundational axioms are drawn from the Quran and Sunnah?

title: 1  What Is Islamic Economics?
text:
1.1 1.1 Introduction: Beyond Halal Economics
Imagine walking into a business conference where the opening speaker asks: “How many of you think Islamic economics is just conventional economics with Islamic rules applied?”
Many hands go up. And it’s an understandable mistake. When people first encounter Islamic economics, they often think of it as a regulatory framework—a set of prohibitions and permissions layered onto mainstream economic practice. Prohibit interest-based financing, add zakat (almsgiving), ensure halal (permissible) operations, and you’ve got Islamic economics, right?
Not quite.
Islamic economics is not conventional economics with Islamic constraints added as an afterthought. Instead, it represents a fundamentally different way of organizing economic life, rooted in a worldview that stands apart from both Western capitalism and Eastern communism. It begins not with efficiency or utility maximization, but with a claim about the nature of reality itself: that God is one, that He alone owns all things, and that humans are placed on earth as trustees with specific obligations and purposes.
This is the distinction we’ll explore in this chapter. Islamic economics flows from tawhid—the oneness of God—and this foundation shapes everything that follows: how we understand property rights, how we define economic welfare, what we consider rational behavior, and what purposes the economy should serve.

title: 1  What Is Islamic Economics?
text:
1.1.1 Why This Matters
Consider a practical question: Should a company maximize profit above all else?
In conventional neoclassical economics, the answer is typically yes—shareholder value maximization is the dominant corporate goal. A few economists and ethicists challenge this, but it remains the standard assumption.
In Islamic economics, the answer is no—not because profit is unimportant, but because profit is one objective among several, and not the highest one. A company should pursue profit in ways that preserve faith, protect the vulnerable, contribute to society, and remain conscious of accountability before God.
These are not minor differences. They reshape how we think about trade, finance, labor, poverty, and even the very meaning of “the economy.”

section: 1.2 1.2 The Islamic Worldview: Tawhid as Economic Foundation
text:
1.2 1.2 The Islamic Worldview: Tawhid as Economic Foundation
The Arabic term tawhid (توحيد) means “making one” or “unification.” In Islamic theology and philosophy, tawhid refers to the doctrine of God’s absolute oneness and uniqueness—that there is no god but God (La ilaha illallah), and nothing shares His essence, nature, or sovereignty.
But tawhid is more than a theological statement. It’s a comprehensive worldview that shapes how Muslims understand reality, knowledge, morality, society, and—crucially—economic life.

1.2.1 The Economic Implications of Tawhid
Three principles follow directly from tawhid:
1. Absolute Divine Ownership
Allah says in the Quran:






NoteQuranic Foundation



“To Allah belongs all that is in the heavens and all that is on the earth. Indeed, Allah is the Rich [free of need], the Praiseworthy.” (Quran 22:64)


This verse is not poetic flourish. It establishes the fundamental ownership structure of the universe. God owns everything—not metaphorically, but in the most real sense. The land, the seas, the minerals, the energy, the human talents, and yes, even what we think of as “my property.”
When you own a house or inherit wealth, you don’t own it in the same way God owns creation. Your ownership is delegated. It is conditional, temporary, and subject to obligations. It is amanah—a trust.






TipKey Concept



Amanah (الأمانة): A trust or deposit. In Islamic economics, all property owned by humans is amanah—a trust from God. This transforms the meaning of property rights from absolute dominion to conditional stewardship.


2. Humans as Trustees (Khalifah)
Closely related to absolute divine ownership is the concept of human stewardship. God appointed humans as khalifah (خليفة)—vicegerents or trustees—on earth:






NoteQuranic Foundation



“And [mention, O Muhammad], when your Lord said to the angels, ‘Indeed, I will make upon the earth a khalifah.’ They said, ‘Will You place therein one who causes corruption therein and sheds blood, while we exalt in praise of You and sanctify You?’ He said, ‘Indeed, I know that which you do not know.’” (Quran 2:30)


This is a tremendous responsibility. Humans are given intellect, will, and agency—the capacity to develop resources, build societies, and make choices. But this power is not absolute autonomy. It is stewardship under scrutiny.
The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:






ImportantHadith Reference



“The best of you are those who are best to their families, and I am the best among you to my family. And the Day of Judgment, none of you will believe until you desire for your brother what you desire for yourself.” (Tirmidhi)
And in another hadith: “All of you are trustees (raa’in), and all of you are responsible for your trust (ra’iyah).” (Sahih Bukhari)


A trustee is accountable. She cannot use the trust for personal indulgence while the beneficiary (in this case, God’s creation and all people) suffers. She cannot destroy or waste. She must develop, protect, and ensure equitable benefit.

section: 1.3 1.3 Khilafah: The Nature of Economic Stewardship
text:
1.3 1.3 Khilafah: The Nature of Economic Stewardship
The concept of khilafah (خلافة)—trusteeship or vicegerency—gives concrete shape to the abstract principle of tawhid. It is the bridge between theology and economics.

1.3.1 Property Rights as Stewardship, Not Domination
In conventional Western law, property ownership often carries the right to use, abuse, or destroy. You own your land; you can do with it largely as you please (subject to zoning laws and nuisance ordinances, perhaps, but the presumption is yours).
Islamic law recognizes ownership (milk) but defines it differently. Your ownership comes with obligations:

The obligation to develop: You cannot let productive resources sit idle. The Prophet said that whoever revives dead land owns it—but the imam (community leader) may also assign it to someone who will work it.
The obligation to preserve: You cannot waste (israf) or cause unnecessary harm (darar). These are prohibited in Islamic law.
The obligation to share: You must pay zakat on wealth, support those unable to work, and not hoard while others go hungry.







WarningCommon Misconception



Misconception: Islamic economics is about communal ownership of everything.
Clarification: Islamic law explicitly recognizes private property and commerce. You can own land, capital, businesses, and goods. The difference from pure laissez-faire capitalism is that ownership comes with stewardship obligations and is bounded by the rights of others and the common welfare.




1.3.2 The Khalifah’s Dual Obligation
A khalifah (trustee) has two fundamental duties:

To develop (ta’mir — تعمير): Bring resources into productive use. Extract minerals responsibly. Plant forests. Build infrastructure. Grow the economy. Technological innovation and productivity growth are virtuous in Islam because they fulfill the khalifah’s role as developer.
To preserve (hifz — حفظ): Do not destroy what God has created. Do not pollute waters knowing it harms others. Do not extract resources in ways that will leave deserts for your grandchildren. Do not prioritize short-term gain over long-term sustainability.

These two obligations are in tension. Development without preservation becomes exploitation. Preservation without development becomes stagnation. The art of Islamic economic policy is holding these in creative balance.

section: 1.4 1.4 Akhirah: The Hereafter as Economic Motivator
text:
1.4 1.4 Akhirah: The Hereafter as Economic Motivator
Here is a question that conventional economics rarely asks: Why would a person refrain from lying, cheating, or stealing if no one would ever find out and there were no legal consequences?
Conventional economics assumes that without external enforcement, people behave according to self-interest. Islamic economics offers a different answer: because God observes, records, and will hold you accountable.
The Quran repeatedly emphasizes that nothing is hidden from God:






NoteQuranic Foundation



“And [mention when] We said to the angels, ‘Prostrate before Adam,’ and they prostrated, except Iblees. He refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers. And We said, ‘O Adam, dwell, you and your wife, in Paradise and eat therefrom in [ease and] abundance from wherever you will. But do not approach this tree, lest you be among the wrongdoers.’” (Quran 2:34-35)
And: “And with Him are the keys of the unseen; none knows them except Him. And He knows what is on the land and in the sea. Not a leaf falls but that He knows it. And no grain is there within the darknesses of the earth and no moist or dry [thing] but that it is [written] in a clear record.” (Quran 6:59)


The concept of akhirah (آخرة)—the hereafter, the eternal life after this world—fundamentally changes economic behavior. If you believe that:

Every action is recorded
You will be questioned about your wealth on the Day of Judgment
The consequences of your choices extend eternally
You will face those you wronged

…then your economic calculus shifts. Cheating loses its appeal not because you fear being caught today, but because you cannot hide from ultimate accountability.
The Prophet said:






ImportantHadith Reference



“On the Day of Judgment, the feet of a servant will not move [from their position] until they are asked about four things: how they spent their life, how they spent their wealth, where they acquired it, and how they spent it.” (Tirmidhi and others)
And: “Seek to know God in prosperity, and He will know you in adversity.” (Tirmidhi)



1.4.1 Reshaping the Time Horizon
In conventional economic models, we use a discount rate to value the future. Money or welfare today is worth more than the same amount tomorrow. This makes economic sense for loans and investments.
But Islamic economics doesn’t just use a discount rate. It extends the time horizon infinitely. Your decisions today affect not just your financial security this year, but your eternal standing. This changes:

Labor decisions: You shouldn’t exploit workers even if it maximizes profit, because you will answer for it.
Environmental choices: You shouldn’t pollute rivers even if it’s cheap, because creation is a trust.
Financial dealings: You shouldn’t engage in riba (usury) even if it’s profitable, because it violates divine law.
Consumption: You shouldn’t waste even if you’re wealthy, because you’ll be asked to justify it.

1.5 1.5 The Sources of Islamic Law and Reasoning
How do we know what is permissible or forbidden in economic transactions? How do we develop Islamic economic policy when the Quran doesn’t spell out every detail?
Islamic jurisprudence (fiqh) relies on four primary sources, arranged in order of authority:

1.5.1 The Sources Pyramid





graph TD
    A["1. QURAN<br/>(Qur'an)"]
    B["2. SUNNAH<br/>(Prophetic Traditions)"]
    C["3. IJMA'<br/>(Scholarly Consensus)"]
    D["4. QIYAS<br/>(Analogical Reasoning)"]

    A --> E["Islamic Economic Rulings"]
    B --> E
    C --> E
    D --> E

    F["IJTIHAD (Independent Legal Reasoning)<br/>Applied throughout the methodology"]
    F -.-> E








1.5.2 1. The Quran
The Quran is the primary source—the word of God. It provides foundational principles, specific rulings on certain transactions, and broad guidance. On matters of economic law, the Quran covers:

Prohibition of riba (interest/usury): Quran 2:275-279, 3:130, 4:161
Requirement of zakat: Quran 9:60
Rules of commerce and contracts: Quran 2:282-283
Justice in trade: Quran 6:152, 11:85
Prohibition of fraud: Quran 83:1-3

What the Quran doesn’t do is provide a complete economic code. There are no verses setting specific tax rates, describing optimal corporate structures, or detailing modern financial instruments. This is where the other sources come in.


1.5.3 2. The Sunnah
The Sunnah—the practices and teachings of Prophet Muhammad—provides the second source. The Prophet’s example and explicit rulings cover many matters the Quran addresses generally:






ImportantHadith Reference



“The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said: ‘The best earnings are those from one’s own labor, and [the earnings of] an honest merchant.’” (Sunan Ibn Majah)
“Whoever cheats us is not from us.” (Sahih Muslim)
“The most evil path to livelihood is one that involves devouring the orphan’s wealth.” (Sunan Ibn Majah)


The Sunnah also provides practical examples—how the Prophet conducted trade, how he treated workers and debtors, how he dealt with monopolies and price manipulation.


1.5.4 3. Ijma (Scholarly Consensus)
Ijma (إجماع) is the consensus of qualified Islamic scholars on a particular issue. If Islamic scholars across different regions and generations have agreed on something, this agreement constitutes binding evidence.






TipKey Concept



Ijma (إجماع): Consensus of Islamic legal scholars. When scholars agree on a ruling, this agreement constitutes binding evidence for Islamic law. Ijma provides a mechanism for adapting Islamic law to new circumstances while maintaining continuity.


Why is consensus important for economics? Because economic life changes. The Quran was revealed in the 7th century. Today we have stock markets, derivatives, insurance, cryptocurrency, and artificial intelligence. On many of these issues, the Quran and Sunnah don’t speak directly. Scholars must reason by analogy and seek consensus.
For example, Islamic scholars have reached consensus that: - Life insurance with element of charity is permissible - Trading in stocks of permissible companies is permissible - Bonds based on fixed interest are not permissible (though some newer forms of Islamic bonds are being developed)


1.5.5 4. Qiyas (Analogical Reasoning)
Qiyas (القياس) means “measurement” or “analogy.” It’s the process of applying an existing ruling to a new case based on a shared underlying principle.
Here’s an example: The Quran explicitly forbids riba in the context of loans and mentions dates, barley, salt, and wheat as items subject to specific trading rules (Sahih Muslim 1594). Why these items? Islamic scholars reasoned that the underlying principle is that these items are ribawi—they are commodities that tend to be stored and used as currency. Later scholars applied this principle to modern currencies, extending the riba prohibition to them.






TipKey Concept



Qiyas (القياس): Analogical reasoning. When the Quran or Sunnah doesn’t directly address a new situation, Islamic jurists apply principles from existing rulings to the new case. Qiyas is the mechanism through which Islamic law adapts to technological and social change.




1.5.6 Ijtihad: The Engine of Adaptation
Running through all four sources is ijtihad (اجتهاد)—literally, “striving” or “exertion.” Ijtihad is independent reasoning by a qualified scholar to derive rulings from the sources of Islamic law.
Why is ijtihad crucial for Islamic economics? Because the world changes. Twenty-first-century economies look completely different from seventh-century commerce. Without ijtihad, Islamic law would be frozen in time. With it, Islamic economics can address modern challenges—digital currencies, algorithmic trading, environmental destruction, artificial intelligence—while remaining faithful to its principles.
However, ijtihad is not freestyle interpretation. It must be grounded in the sources, guided by established methodologies, and conducted by scholars with deep knowledge.






WarningCommon Misconception



Misconception: Islamic economics is static; it has fixed answers for everything.
Clarification: Islamic economics is both principled and dynamic. The foundational principles (justice, trust, accountability) are fixed. But how those principles apply to new situations requires ijtihad—careful reasoning within established frameworks.

1.6 1.6 Maqasid al-Shariah: The Objectives of Islamic Law
If Islamic law has sources and methodologies, it also has purposes—objectives that the law is meant to achieve. These are called maqasid al-shariah (مقاصد الشريعة).
The classical scholar al-Ghazali (1058-1111) identified five fundamental objectives of Islamic law that all legal rules exist to protect:

1.6.1 The Five Maqasid





graph LR
    A["MAQASID AL-SHARIAH<br/>(Objectives of Islamic Law)"]

    A --> B["1. Preservation of FAITH<br/>(Hifz al-Din)"]
    A --> C["2. Preservation of LIFE<br/>(Hifz al-Nafs)"]
    A --> D["3. Preservation of INTELLECT<br/>(Hifz al-Aql)"]
    A --> E["4. Preservation of LINEAGE<br/>(Hifz al-Nasl)"]
    A --> F["5. Preservation of WEALTH<br/>(Hifz al-Mal)"]

    B --> G["Guides Economic Policy"]
    C --> G
    D --> G
    E --> G
    F --> G






1. Preservation of Faith (Hifz al-Din)
The first objective is to protect and preserve religious faith. In economic terms, this means: - Economic life should not corrupt faith or lead people away from God - Believers should have time and resources to fulfill religious obligations (prayer, pilgrimage, worship) - Economic institutions should reinforce rather than undermine moral values
This is why practices that involve deception or explicit forbidden elements are prohibited—not just because they’re inefficient, but because they corrupt the soul.
2. Preservation of Life (Hifz al-Nafs)
The second objective is to protect human life and well-being. This is comprehensive: - Ensuring food security and nutrition - Preventing poverty and destitution - Providing healthcare and safety - Protecting against exploitation and abuse
In economic terms, this means the economy should serve human survival and flourishing, not sacrifice people to abstract goals like GDP growth.
3. Preservation of Intellect (Hifz al-Aql)
The third objective is to protect human rationality and knowledge. This includes: - Education and knowledge acquisition - Protection against intoxicants and mind-altering substances - Freedom of thought and expression - Development of human potential
Economically, this justifies investment in education, research, and institutions that develop human capability.
4. Preservation of Lineage (Hifz al-Nasl)
The fourth objective is to protect family and future generations. This includes: - Rules governing marriage and family relations - Prohibitions on abandoning children - Protection of inheritance rights - Long-term thinking about environmental and social sustainability
Economically, this means avoiding short-termism. You cannot maximize profit today if it destroys the resources and environment your children will inherit.
5. Preservation of Wealth (Hifz al-Mal)
The fifth objective is to protect property and economic security. Islamic law: - Recognizes private property and trade - Prohibits theft and fraud - Establishes rules for contracts and commerce - Protects workers’ rights and lender/borrower obligations
Importantly, “preservation of wealth” doesn’t mean wealth in the hands of the few. It means protecting everyone’s economic security and preventing exploitation.


1.6.2 Applying the Maqasid to Economic Policy
Here’s how the five objectives work as a policy compass:
Example: Should we allow a factory to operate near a residential neighborhood if it employs many people but pollutes air and water?
Using the maqasid: - Faith: Does pollution offend Islamic values? Yes—it violates the trust of stewardship - Life: Does the pollution harm health? If yes, preservation of life takes precedence - Intellect: Are there alternative technologies that could reduce pollution? This reflects the khalifah’s duty to develop responsibly - Lineage: Will this pollution harm future generations? If yes, this violates their rights - Wealth: The factory creates economic security for workers, but it also destroys the wealth of those whose health it harms
The maqasid suggest that permitting the factory without pollution controls violates multiple objectives. Requiring pollution controls, even if this reduces profitability, aligns with Islamic economic principles.






TipKey Concept



Maqasid al-Shariah (مقاصد الشريعة): The objectives of Islamic law—preservation of faith, life, intellect, lineage, and wealth. These five objectives serve as the ultimate purpose of all Islamic rules and as a guide for economic policy.

text:
1.7 1.7 Islamic Economics vs. Conventional Economics: A Comparison
Now that we’ve explored the foundations of Islamic economics, let’s compare it directly with conventional approaches. This comparison shows where they overlap and where they diverge.

1.7.1 Key Overlaps
Despite these differences, Islamic economics and conventional economics overlap significantly:

Markets work: Both recognize that voluntary exchange and price mechanisms are efficient ways to allocate resources.
Incentives matter: Both understand that people respond to incentives.
Efficiency is valuable: Islamic economists don’t deliberately choose inefficiency; they just don’t elevate it above all other values.
Specialization and trade benefit everyone: The principle of comparative advantage applies in Islamic economics as much as conventional.
Capital and investment are necessary: Economic development requires productive capital.



1.7.2 Key Divergences
The fundamental differences stem from worldview:

Purpose: Conventional economics aims at maximum material well-being. Islamic economics subordinates material prosperity to moral and spiritual well-being.
Constraints: Conventional economics has few constraints beyond legal ones. Islamic economics has constraints rooted in faith and ethics.
Time horizon: Conventional economics discounts the future. Islamic economics doesn’t—your actions have eternal consequences.
Motivation: Conventional economics assumes self-interest is primary. Islamic economics assumes humans can and should act from other motives too—fear of God, community responsibility, family duty.
Justice: For conventional economics, fairness is secondary to efficiency. For Islamic economics, justice is primary; an efficient system that’s unjust is unacceptable.







ImportantHadith Reference



The Prophet Muhammad emphasized the integration of material and spiritual:
“In this world, work as if you will live forever. In the hereafter, work as if you will die tomorrow.”
This captures the Islamic economic perspective: take this world and your economic responsibilities seriously (work hard, develop resources, grow the economy). But always remember your larger purpose and ultimate accountability.

text:
1.8 1.8 Summary and Key Takeaways
Islamic economics is not conventional economics with Islamic rules applied. It is a distinct discipline with its own foundations, axioms, and objectives.
The foundations rest on three pillars:

Tawhid (God’s Oneness): All resources belong to God; humans are trustees, not absolute owners.
Khilafah (Stewardship): Humans have the obligation to develop resources while preserving them, to improve society while remaining accountable.
Akhirah (The Hereafter): Belief in eternal accountability shapes economic behavior in ways that conventional incentives don’t.

Islamic law develops through:

The Quran (primary source) providing foundational principles
The Sunnah (prophetic example) providing practical guidance
Ijma (scholarly consensus) adapting law to new contexts
Qiyas (analogical reasoning) extending principles to novel situations
Ijtihad (independent reasoning) enabling the law to address contemporary challenges

The purposes of Islamic law (maqasid al-shariah) are:

Preservation of faith
Preservation of life
Preservation of intellect
Preservation of lineage
Preservation of wealth

These five objectives guide both Islamic legal reasoning and economic policy.
Comparing Islamic and conventional economics:

They overlap in recognizing markets, incentives, specialization, and capital
They diverge in purpose, time horizon, motivation, and understanding of justice
Islamic economics is neither socialist nor capitalist; it’s a distinct approach


1.8.1 Why This Matters for the Rest of This Course
As we move forward in this textbook, we’ll see how these foundations shape specific economic institutions and policies:

How the khalifah concept reshapes corporate governance (Chapter 3)
How the maqasid guide monetary and fiscal policy (Part 3)
How Islamic finance instruments reflect these principles (Part 4)
How workers’ rights and environmental protection flow from these foundations (Part 5)

You cannot understand any of these applications without grasping the foundations laid in this chapter. Islamic economics is not a miscellaneous collection of rules. It’s a coherent system flowing from a distinct worldview.


1.8.2 Reflecting on the Big Picture
Before moving to the next chapter, consider:

How would your own economic decisions change if you believed you would be asked to account for every choice on the Day of Judgment?
If property is ultimately God’s and you’re a trustee, how should this affect your long-term planning?
How should the need to develop resources (khalifah’s first obligation) be balanced against preserving them (khalifah’s second obligation)?
Of the five maqasid, which do you think conventional economics neglects most?

These are not abstract questions. They shape real decisions in real lives.

title: 2  Thinking Like an Islamic Economist
text:
2.1 Introduction: The Economist’s Perspective
When an economist looks at the world, she sees patterns, relationships, and tradeoffs. She might see that people buy fewer lattes when coffee prices rise. She might notice that firms produce more output when labor becomes cheaper. She observes that governments face a fundamental tension between the services they want to provide and the taxes they can collect. These observations lead economists to build models—simplified representations of reality that help us understand complex systems.
The British economist John Maynard Keynes once quipped that “the difficulty lies, not in the new ideas, but in escaping from the old ones.” This observation applies powerfully to Islamic economics. An Islamic economist must think differently not because the basic tools of analysis change, but because the foundational assumptions—the axioms upon which all analysis rests—are different.
Consider this: A conventional economist analyzing charitable giving might model it as follows: A wealthy individual has income Y, consumption desires C, and gives to charity only when her marginal utility from an additional dollar of consumption falls below her satisfaction from giving. She stops giving when these utilities equalize. The model predicts that as income rises, charitable giving increases, but typically as a smaller fraction of income.
An Islamic economist might say something quite different: A wealthy individual holds wealth as a trust from Allah. She is obligated to give zakat (2.5% annually on certain types of wealth) not as a discretionary act dependent on utility preferences, but as a commanded pillar of faith. Her utility function includes both worldly consumption and obedience to divine command, weighted by her belief in ultimate accountability. The model predicts that Islamic obligations to give are stable across income levels (as a percentage), while additional voluntary sadaqah varies with preference and circumstance.
These two models predict different behaviors. More importantly, they rest on different views of human nature itself.
This chapter introduces how economists—including Islamic economists—think in models and frameworks. It shows how Islamic economics maintains continuity with powerful analytical methods while fundamentally transforming their foundation.

text:
2.2 The Circular Flow of the Islamic Economy
Every first-year economics course begins with the circular flow of goods, services, and money. The standard diagram shows households and firms exchanging labor and capital for goods and services, with governments taxing and spending. It’s elegant, illuminating, and fundamentally incomplete when applied to an Islamic economic framework.
The Islamic circular flow must account for additional institutions and flows that reflect Islamic principles. Let’s build it step by step.

Notice several key features absent from the standard circular flow:
The Zakat Flow: Zakat is not merely taxation—it has theological and social significance. The Qur’an places zakat among the pillars of faith alongside belief and prayer. It flows from the wealthy to the poor as a right of the poor, not a charity granted by the generous.






NoteQuranic Foundation



“Alms are only for the poor and the needy, and those who work to collect them, and those whose hearts have been brought together [for Islam], and for freeing slaves and those in debt, and for the cause of Allah, and for the wayfarer; this is an obligation from Allah. And Allah is all-knowing and wise.” (Qur’an 9:60)
“In their wealth there is a recognized right for the needy and the deprived.” (Qur’an 51:19)


The Waqf Sector: While the standard circular flow implies two main institutional sectors (households and firms), the Islamic economy recognizes a third: the waqf sector. A waqf is an endowment—typically real property donated in perpetuity for a charitable or public purpose. The waqf sector creates hospitals, schools, water systems, and other public goods. Unlike taxation, waqf is voluntary; unlike firms, waqf does not distribute profits to shareholders; unlike government, waqf operates with decentralized initiative and local knowledge.






ImportantHadith Reference



The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: “When a person dies, their deeds end except for three: a continuous charity [waqf], knowledge that benefits [people], or a righteous child who makes dua for them.” (Hadith: Sahih Muslim)
This hadith establishes the perpetual nature of waqf—unlike ordinary charity that exhausts itself when given, a waqf continues generating benefit across generations.


Hisbah and Market Supervision: The conventional circular flow is silent on how markets function. Islamic economics recognizes an institution of hisbah—market supervision to prevent fraud, ensure fair dealing, and correct market failures. The muhtasib (market supervisor) has authority to inspect goods, prevent hoarding, stop harmful monopolies, and maintain standards of weights and measures.






TipKey Concept



Hisbah (literally “reckoning” or “accountability”) is the institutional framework for ensuring that market transactions comply with Islamic principles. It prevents gharar (deception), riba (exploitation through interest), and talaqqi al-rukban (intercepting merchants before they reach markets to impose unfair prices).


Profit-Sharing Instead of Interest: Notice what’s absent from our Islamic circular flow: interest-based flows between sectors. In conventional banking, firms borrow from banks at interest; households borrow for mortgages at interest. In Islamic finance, these relationships are reframed. Firms finance expansion through mudaraba (partnership with profit-sharing) or musharaka (equity partnership). Households finance homes through ijara (leasing-to-own) or murabaha (cost-plus purchase agreements). The circular flow of money continues, but the nature of the relationship changes from debtor-creditor (with interest) to partners or co-owners.
This is more than accounting semantics. The relationships among economic actors change fundamentally. In interest-based finance, the lender extracts value regardless of the borrower’s success. In profit-sharing finance, the lender succeeds only when the borrower succeeds. Incentives align differently.






WarningCommon Misconception



Many people mistakenly believe that Islamic economics simply replaces “interest” with “profit-sharing” while keeping everything else unchanged. In fact, the shift redefines the relationships among households, firms, and financial institutions throughout the circular flow. It affects risk-bearing, monitoring, contract design, and institutional structure.

section: 2.3 The Agent-Trustee Paradigm vs. Homo Economicus
text:
2.3 The Agent-Trustee Paradigm vs. Homo Economicus
At the heart of modern economics sits a deceptively simple assumption: individuals are rational and self-interested. They make decisions to maximize their own utility. This figure—homo economicus—has become so embedded in economic thinking that economists sometimes forget it’s an assumption rather than a fact about human nature.
Islamic economics, while embracing rational decision-making, fundamentally rejects the narrow self-interest assumption. Instead, it adopts the agent-trustee paradigm.

2.3.1 Homo Economicus: The Conventional Framework
In conventional economic theory, an individual i chooses a consumption bundle \((c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_n)\) and labor supply \(\ell\) to maximize a utility function:
\[U_i = U_i(c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_n, \ell)\]
subject to budget constraints. The individual is rational: she correctly understands her options, perceives probabilities accurately, and chooses the option that best satisfies her preferences. She is selfish: her utility depends on her own consumption and leisure, not on others’ wellbeing (though altruism can be incorporated as a preference).
This model generates powerful predictions: people work less when wages fall, save more when interest rates rise, and consume more of goods whose prices fall. It explains much observed behavior with elegant simplicity.
But homo economicus has limitations that Islamic economics highlights:

Unlimited Desires: The model assumes preferences and budget constraints, but doesn’t constrain what preferences might be. It allows for any set of preferences (gluttony, greed, displays of status) as long as they’re consistent. Islamic economics, by contrast, teaches that some desires are harmful and should be constrained through moral formation.
Temporal Myopia: Homo economicus is interested in maximizing lifetime utility, but “lifetime” means the earthly lifetime. Islamic economics introduces the concept of akhirah (the afterlife) as a genuine component of rational decision-making. A person rationally considers not just worldly consequences but eternal consequences.
Isolation: Homo economicus makes decisions in isolation. His preferences are his own. Islamic economics emphasizes ibadah (worship) and ukhuwwah (brotherhood)—decisions are made within a community of believers with shared values and mutual obligations.
Autonomy: Homo economicus answers to no one but himself. Islamic economics places the individual as khalifah (vicegerent) of Allah, answerable to a higher power and hence constrained by divine guidance.



2.3.2 The Agent-Trustee Paradigm
Islamic economics proposes a different foundational image: the individual as wakil (agent) and amin (trustee).
Wealth is not ultimately owned but held in trust. The Qur’an is explicit:






NoteQuranic Foundation



“Believe in Allah and His Messenger, and spend out of that wherein Allah has made you successors [khalifahs].” (Qur’an 57:7)
“It is not your wealth and your children that bring you nearer in closeness to Us—except for those who believe and do righteous deeds.” (Qur’an 34:37)


This reframes decision-making. When I choose how much to consume and save, I’m not asking merely “What maximizes my pleasure?” but “What am I answerable to Allah for?” When I decide whether to engage in usury or fraud, I’m not weighing utility against risk, but weighing obedience against disobedience.
The Islamic utility function might be written as:
\[U_i = U_i(c_i, \ell_i, \Psi_i, \theta_i) + \Omega_i\]
where: - \(c_i\) = consumption in the current world - \(\ell_i\) = leisure in the current world - \(\Psi_i\) = obedience to divine commands (performing obligatory acts, avoiding prohibitions) - \(\theta_i\) = social contributions (giving sadaqah, maintaining family ties, treating workers justly) - \(\Omega_i\) = expected reward or punishment in the afterlife, discounted by belief
Notice that utility now has multiple dimensions. An action that increases \(c_i\) but decreases \(\Psi_i\) might decrease overall utility. A choice that reduces worldly income (\(c_i\) falls) but increases \(\theta_i\) might increase overall utility.


2.3.3 How This Changes Economic Predictions
These different frameworks predict different behaviors. Let’s consider several concrete examples:
Labor Supply: Homo economicus works more when wages rise (positive substitution effect dominates). Under the agent-trustee paradigm, high wages might reduce work because: - Islamic teaching discourages needless accumulation (“The best of you are those who are best to their families, and I am best among you to my family”) - Beyond sufficiency, additional consumption yields little marginal utility - Time might be better allocated to worship, family, or community service
Empirically, Muslim-majority countries show complex labor supply patterns that don’t always match conventional predictions, suggesting that motivations beyond wage optimization are at work.
Honest Dealing: Homo economicus cheats when expected gains from fraud exceed expected losses (i.e., when \(P \times F > B\) where \(P\) is the probability of being caught, \(F\) is the fine, and \(B\) is the benefit). If I can cheat and escape detection, I should. Islamic economics predicts less cheating because: - Divine surveillance is certain (\(P = 1\) from the perspective of belief) - Punishment is not merely legal but eternal - Cheating violates the trusteeship relationship with Allah
This predicts more trust-based relationships and lower transaction costs in Islamic communities—an empirically observable difference.
Charitable Giving: Homo economicus gives when marginal utility of consumption equals marginal utility of giving. Islamic economics predicts giving zakat regardless of utility preferences because: - Zakat is obligatory, not optional - The poor have a right to zakat, not a recipient of charity - Withholding zakat is disobedience to Allah
This predicts that Islamic giving is more stable and less responsive to income fluctuations than conventional charity.
Interest and Finance: Homo economicus accepts interest-based borrowing because it allows consumption smoothing and investment. Islamic economics predicts avoidance of interest because: - Interest is explicitly prohibited (haram) - The agent-trustee relationship forbids profiting from another’s need - Profit-sharing aligns incentives better than extraction
This predicts preference for partnership-based finance even when interest-based finance is available—something increasingly observed in Islamic finance markets.






TipKey Concept



The agent-trustee paradigm doesn’t make individuals irrational. It makes them differently rational—optimizing over a different set of values. An engineer optimizes for safety; an artist for beauty; an Islamic economist optimizes for obedience plus worldly wellbeing. Different objectives, same rational method.

text:
2.4 Methodology in Islamic Economics
How do we actually do Islamic economics? What methods and approaches do we use to generate knowledge about economic systems? This is a question of methodology—the logic underlying our analysis.

2.4.1 Positive vs. Normative Economics in the Islamic Context
Conventional economics distinguishes between:

Positive economics: Describes how the economy actually works. “When the government raises the minimum wage, employment falls” (or rises, depending on empirical evidence). Positive statements can be tested against evidence.
Normative economics: Prescribes how the economy should work. “The government should raise the minimum wage to reduce poverty.” Normative statements involve values and cannot be tested scientifically.

Islamic economics accepts this distinction but handles it differently because of its theological foundation.
In conventional economics, positive economics is objective and value-neutral; normative economics is subjective and value-laden. The economist can describe how markets work without endorsing market outcomes.
In Islamic economics, positive economics remains objective—we still ask “Do interest-bearing markets function as predicted?” and examine evidence. But normative economics is constrained by revelation, not merely by contemporary values. The Islamic economist says: “Society should incorporate zakat because Allah has commanded it,” not “Society should incorporate zakat if we happen to value redistribution.”
This creates an interesting methodological position. Islamic economists:

Accept empirical constraints: If profit-sharing finance proves inferior to interest-based finance in functioning, this is a fact we must account for (though we might then work to improve profit-sharing mechanisms)
Accept theological constraints: We don’t ask “Should we follow Islamic rules?” as though this is optional. We ask “How do we best implement Islamic rules given economic reality?”
Use standard analytical methods: The mathematical tools, graphical analysis, and statistical methods are value-neutral. We use them to analyze both conventional and Islamic systems.

The result is that positive and normative merge somewhat. We can ask: “What economic institutions would simultaneously maximize human flourishing and comply with Islamic teaching?” This is neither purely positive nor purely normative in the conventional sense—it combines empirical analysis with theological constraints.


2.4.2 The Role of Revelation Alongside Empirical Observation
In conventional economics, knowledge comes from observation and reason: we see patterns in data and construct theories to explain them. The method is inductive (from observation to theory) and deductive (from theory to prediction).
Islamic economics accepts observation and reason but adds revelation. The Qur’an and Hadith provide direct guidance on:

What constitutes legitimate profit (riba is forbidden; just pricing is required)
How property should be treated (property rights are real but limited; waste is forbidden)
What institutional arrangements are necessary (zakat, waqf, shura/consultation)
What human motivations matter (not only consumption, but also obedience and accountability)

This creates a three-source methodology:

Islamic economics synthesizes these three sources. If all three align—revelation requires it, observation shows it works, and analysis explains why—we have strong foundations for a policy. If revelation requires something that observation shows fails, Islamic economists ask deeper questions about implementation.






ImportantHadith Reference



The Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said: “He is not of us who does not treat the young with affection and respect the old.” (Hadith: Tirmidhi)
This hadith provides direct normative guidance (treating the young with affection and the old with respect). An Islamic economist might then ask empirically: “What economic institutions encourage such behavior?” and analytically: “How do we design policies implementing this principle?”




2.4.3 The Axioms of Islamic Economic Analysis
All economic analysis rests on axioms—foundational assumptions taken as true. In conventional economics, these include:

Individuals are rational and self-interested
Markets tend toward equilibrium
Rational individuals accurately assess probabilities
Preferences are stable over time

Islamic economics maintains many axioms but modifies others:

These different axioms don’t make Islamic economic analysis less rigorous—they make it differently rigorous. The mathematics, logic, and empirical methods remain equally demanding.

text:
2.5 Key Analytical Tools
Islamic economists employ the same toolkit as conventional economists—mathematical optimization, supply and demand curves, regression analysis—but apply it within the framework of modified axioms. Let’s examine several key tools:

2.5.1 Modified Utility Functions
The conventional utility function \(U(c, \ell)\) depending on consumption and leisure becomes more complex:
\[U_i = \alpha c_i + \beta m_i + \gamma \psi_i + \delta \omega_i\]
where: - \(c_i\) = consumption (worldly) - \(m_i\) = money given in zakat and sadaqah - \(\psi_i\) = measure of religious observance - \(\omega_i\) = altruism toward family and community - \(\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta\) = weights reflecting individual preferences within Islamic bounds
Crucially, \(\beta > 0\) is not optional—it’s obligatory. An individual cannot set \(\beta = 0\) (ignoring zakat) if she wishes to be considered Muslim. But the relative weight varies among individuals and circumstances.
Similarly, consumption itself is constrained: \(c_i^{max}\) exists beyond which additional consumption provides no benefit and may violate Islamic principles of frugality and modesty.
These modified utility functions generate different comparative statics (how outcomes change when parameters shift) than conventional functions. For instance:

As income rises from poverty toward sufficiency, all four components of utility rise
As income rises beyond sufficiency, further consumption increases \(c_i\) but may decrease \(\psi_i\) (if the person becomes distracted by worldly concerns) and \(\omega_i\) (if wealth creates arrogance toward others)
The optimal level of accumulation includes not just personal consumption but reserve for genuine needs, obligations to dependents, and potential charitable giving



2.5.2 Social Welfare Functions Incorporating Maqasid
The maqasid al-shariah (objectives of Islamic law) provide a framework for evaluating societal outcomes. The classical formulation identifies five essential objectives:

Preservation of Religion (din)
Preservation of Life (nafs)
Preservation of Intellect (aql)
Preservation of Property (mal)
Preservation of Family/Lineage (nasl)

These can be formalized in a social welfare function:
\[W = w_1 D + w_2 L + w_3 I + w_4 P + w_5 F\]
where each component measures the degree to which society preserves each maqasid, weighted by relative importance. Policy decisions can be evaluated by their impact on this multi-dimensional welfare function rather than a single measure like GDP.
For example, consider automation in manufacturing: - Conventional analysis: Does automation increase output per worker? (Usually yes → good) - Islamic analysis: Does automation: - Preserve livelihoods for workers who lose jobs? (Property preservation) - Maintain opportunities for people to work with dignity? (Life preservation) - Disrupt family structures through forced migration? (Family preservation) - Allow workers to engage in spiritual development or education? (Intellect preservation)
The Islamic analysis is more complex, but potentially more comprehensive in accounting for human flourishing.






TipKey Concept



Maqasid Analysis evaluates policies not just by their effect on income or consumption, but by their impact on five fundamental objectives that Islamic law exists to protect. A policy might increase GDP but harm family structures or reduce opportunities for religious practice—thus decreasing overall welfare on the maqasid framework.




2.5.3 Maslahah (Public Interest) in Policy Analysis
The concept of maslahah (public interest or general welfare) provides another analytical tool. Islamic jurisprudence allows for consideration of legitimate public interests even when not explicitly mentioned in revelation, provided these interests support the objectives of Islamic law.
In policy analysis, maslahah asks: “Does this policy serve the genuine public interest in a way that aligns with Islamic principles?”
For example: - Interest rate regulation: While riba (interest) is forbidden on lending between individuals, Islamic economists debate whether central banks may set monetary policy rates. Some argue this is a form of modern necessity and public interest; others argue the prohibition is absolute. The maslahah framework allows this debate to proceed systematically.

Environmental protection: While not explicitly detailed in medieval texts, Islamic economists increasingly argue that environmental protection is required by maslahah—we cannot preserve human life if we destroy the ecosystem that sustains it.
Labor rights: While individual labor contracts should be fair, maslahah allows governments to establish minimum wage laws and labor protections as supporting the maqasid of preserving life and family.

Maslahah analysis is more qualitative than utility-maximizing analysis, but it provides a framework for adapting Islamic principles to modern circumstances.

Islamic economics doesn’t exist in isolation. It can be compared and contrasted with other approaches to understanding economies. In many cases, Islamic economics finds unexpected common ground with heterodox schools.

Figure 2.2: Islamic Economics in Relation to Other Schools


2.6.2 Neoclassical Economics
Similarities: - Both use mathematical modeling - Both value efficient allocation of resources - Both recognize the importance of prices in coordinating activity - Both expect individuals to respond to incentives
Differences: - Neoclassical assumes pure self-interest; Islamic economics includes moral and spiritual dimensions - Neoclassical assumes rational agents with good information; Islamic economics acknowledges bounded rationality and the role of revelation - Neoclassical is neutral on institutions; Islamic economics requires specific institutions (zakat, waqf) - Neoclassical celebrates unfettered markets; Islamic economics constrains markets through ethical rules
Common Ground: Both would agree that efficient resource allocation matters. A system that wastes resources fails both tests. Both recognize that incentives drive behavior.


2.6.3 Keynesian Economics
Similarities: - Both emphasize that markets alone may not generate good outcomes - Both accept a role for government or other institutions in coordinating activity - Both recognize that uncertainty and incomplete information matter - Both are concerned with employment and poverty, not just efficiency
Differences: - Keynesian economics is agnostic about the source of market failures; Islamic economics traces them partly to moral failures (greed, fraud) and institutional design - Keynesian fixes focus on aggregate demand and monetary policy; Islamic economics emphasizes institutional design and ethical constraints - Keynesian is concerned with business cycles; Islamic economics is concerned with justice and legitimate profit
Common Ground: Both recognize that unregulated markets can fail. Both accept that unemployment and inequality are genuine economic problems requiring attention.


2.6.4 Institutional Economics
Similarities: - Both emphasize that institutions—not just prices—shape economic outcomes - Both recognize that history and culture matter - Both see economics as embedded in broader social and legal systems - Both question the universality of neoclassical assumptions
Differences: - Institutional economics typically remains secular in its analysis; Islamic economics is explicitly theological - Institutional economics examines actual institutions that emerge; Islamic economics prescribes institutions that should exist - Institutional economics often focuses on efficiency; Islamic economics includes justice as a primary objective
Common Ground: Both reject the notion that economics is merely physics-like analysis of preferences and constraints. Both recognize humans as embedded in institutions that shape their choices.


2.6.5 Behavioral Economics
Similarities: - Both recognize that humans systematically deviate from perfect rationality - Both acknowledge psychological biases (overconfidence, status quo bias, loss aversion) - Both emphasize context and framing effects - Both are skeptical of predictions from homo economicus
Differences: - Behavioral economics typically treats deviations from rationality as errors to overcome; Islamic economics treats certain constraints (like avoiding riba) as wisdom even if they seem economically irrational - Behavioral economics focuses on cognitive limitations; Islamic economics emphasizes moral formation - Behavioral economics suggests improving decision-making; Islamic economics suggests constraining decisions according to principles
Common Ground: Both challenge the neoclassical vision of the hyper-rational, perfectly informed agent. Both believe real economic behavior is more complex and psychologically interesting than textbook models suggest.






TipKey Concept



Islamic economics is perhaps closest to institutional economics in its emphasis on how institutions shape behavior, but it differs in being prescriptive rather than merely descriptive. Islamic economics says: “These institutions (zakat, waqf, hisbah) should exist because they are commanded and because they produce good outcomes.”

2.7 Summary and Key Takeaways
This chapter has introduced how Islamic economists think about economic systems. The key insights are:

Continuity of Methods: Islamic economics uses the same mathematical tools, analytical frameworks, and empirical methods as conventional economics. The difference lies in foundational axioms and objectives, not in rigor.
Extended Institutional Framework: The circular flow of the Islamic economy includes the waqf sector, zakat flows, hisbah oversight, and profit-sharing relationships. These aren’t marginal additions—they fundamentally reshape how economic activity is organized.
Different Conception of Human Nature: The agent-trustee paradigm replaces homo economicus with a vision of individuals as accountable to a higher power, motivated by multiple objectives (worldly and spiritual), and operating within divinely-set constraints. This generates different predictions about behavior.
Synthesis of Sources: Islamic economic knowledge comes from three sources—revelation (Quran and Hadith), empirical observation, and rational analysis. All three inform conclusions.
Modified Analytical Tools: Utility functions expand to include religious observance and altruism; social welfare functions incorporate the maqasid al-shariah; policy analysis uses maslahah to evaluate public interest.
Productive Heterodoxy: Islamic economics shares insights with institutional, Keynesian, and behavioral approaches while differing from neoclassical orthodoxy. It’s part of a broader movement recognizing that humans are embedded in institutions, motivated by multiple values, and systematically rational but not perfectly rational.

The following chapters will build on this foundation. We’ll examine in detail the microeconomics of Islamic firms and households, the macroeconomics of Islamic monetary and fiscal systems, and the applications of Islamic economics to contemporary policy challenges. But all of these examinations will employ the frameworks and methods introduced here: the recognition that economic analysis can be rigorous while being theoretically pluralist, institutionally sensitive, and morally purposeful.

title: Appendix A — Glossary of Key Terms
text:
Glossary of Key Terms
This glossary provides definitions of key terms and concepts in Islamic economics, with both Arabic and English terminology.

title: Appendix A — Glossary of Key Terms
text:
A.1 Terms

Adl (عدل)

Justice and equity; a fundamental principle in Islamic economics emphasizing fair treatment, equitable distribution, and the protection of human dignity in all economic transactions and relations.

Gharar (غرار)

Excessive uncertainty or ambiguity in a contract; prohibited in Islamic law because it undermines informed consent and creates opportunities for exploitation. Covers uncertainty about subject matter, price, or delivery terms.

Hisbah (حسبة)

Market supervision and regulation; the Islamic institution responsible for ensuring fair dealing in markets, preventing fraud, ensuring product quality, and protecting consumers from exploitation.

Ihtikar (احتكار)

Hoarding or artificial monopoly; the prohibition against accumulating goods to create artificial scarcity and inflate prices, designed to prevent exploitation of consumers and maintain market stability.

Ijara (إجارة)

Islamic leasing; a contract where the lessor retains ownership of an asset while the lessee uses it in return for periodic payments, providing an alternative to interest-based financing.

Israf (إسراف)

Extravagance and waste; prohibited in Islamic economics as both morally and economically harmful, encompassing excessive consumption, wasteful spending, and depletion of resources.

Istisna (استصناع)

Manufacturing contract; a financing instrument where a bank agrees to manufacture or construct an asset for a customer at a specified price payable in installments or at delivery.

Maslaha (مصلحة)

Public interest or welfare; a principle in Islamic jurisprudence that prioritizes the well-being of society and the prevention of harm, used to justify regulations protecting public welfare.

Mudarabah (مضاربة)

Profit-sharing partnership; an Islamic financing arrangement where one party (investor) provides capital while another party (entrepreneur) provides labor and management, with profits shared according to agreed proportions.

Murabaha (مرابحة)

Cost-plus sale; an Islamic financing technique where the bank purchases goods and resells them to a client at cost plus a disclosed profit margin, typically with deferred payment.

Musharakah (مشاركة)

Partnership or equity participation; an Islamic financing arrangement where two or more parties contribute capital and management to a business venture and share profits and losses according to agreed proportions.

Nisab (نصاب)

Minimum threshold; the minimum amount of wealth that triggers the obligation to pay zakat, below which no zakat is due. The nisab is calculated for various types of assets.

Riba (ربا)

Usury or interest; the increase in amount when exchanging one thing for another of the same kind, or the time-based charge on loans. Prohibited in Islamic law due to its exploitation and injustice.

Salam (السلم)

Forward sale; a contract where a buyer pays in advance for goods that will be delivered at a future date, commonly used for agricultural products and providing working capital to producers.

Sadaqah (صدقة)

Voluntary charity; any voluntary act of giving to those in need, distinct from zakat as an obligation. Includes regular charitable giving and forms of social welfare beyond the zakat obligation.

Shari’ah (الشريعة)

Islamic law; the body of Islamic jurisprudence derived from the Quran, Sunnah (Prophet’s traditions), ijma (consensus), and qiyas (analogical reasoning), governing all aspects of Muslim life including economic conduct.

Sukuk (صكوك)

Islamic bonds; financial instruments representing ownership shares in real assets or project revenues, providing an alternative to interest-bearing bonds and ensuring creditors share in both risks and returns.

Tabarru (تبرع)

Donation or voluntary contribution; a gratuitous transfer of wealth or benefit; foundational to takaful where participants donate to a mutual fund to cover mutual losses.

Takaful (تكافل)

Mutual aid or cooperation; Islamic insurance based on mutual cooperation and shared responsibility, where participants pool resources to cover losses rather than transferring risk to an insurer.

Tawhid (التوحيد)

Divine unity; the Islamic principle of monotheism emphasizing that all economic activity is ultimately oriented toward serving God’s purpose and maintaining social harmony.

Thaman (ثمن)

Price or monetary value; in Islamic jurisprudence, the measure of value used in transactions, particularly important in regulations about money and ribawi goods.

Wakala (الوكالة)

Agency; a contract where one party (wakil) acts on behalf of another party (muwakkil) for agreed compensation, used in various Islamic financial instruments for management and administration.

Waqf (وقف)

Endowment; a permanent, irrevocable dedication of property for charitable or religious purposes, with returns used to benefit specified beneficiaries. A key institution for long-term social investment.

Wasatiyyah (الوسطية)

Moderation or balance; the Islamic principle of maintaining equilibrium and avoiding extremes in consumption, spending, and economic behavior—a cornerstone of Islamic economic ethics.

Zakat (الزكاة)

Obligatory alms or wealth tax; a mandatory transfer of wealth to specified categories of poor and needy persons, calculated as a small percentage of eligible assets held above the nisab threshold.

Recommended Reading
This reading list provides curated selections of foundational, contemporary, and specialized works in Islamic economics, organized by topic for easy reference.

title: Appendix C — Recommended Reading
section: C.1 Foundational Works in Islamic Economics
text:
C.1 Foundational Works in Islamic Economics

Chapra, Muhammad Umer. The Islamic Welfare State and Its Role in the Economy. Leicester: Islamic Foundation, 1992.

Comprehensive exploration of the Islamic state’s role in economic management and social welfare.

Khan, Muhammad Akram. Islamic Economics and Finance: A Glossary. London: Routledge, 2nd edition, 2003.

Accessible reference work defining key concepts and terminology in Islamic economics.

Kahf, Monzer. Islamic Economics: Notes on Definition and Methodology. Journal of Research in Islamic Economics, 1989.

Methodological foundation for understanding Islamic economics as a distinct discipline.

Maududi, Abu A’la. Economic System of Islam. Lahore: Islamic Publications, 1984.

Classic exposition of Islamic economic principles from a prominent Islamic scholar.

Naqvi, Syed Nawab Haider. Ethics and Economics: An Islamic Synthesis. Leicester: Islamic Foundation, 1981.

Integration of ethical principles with economic analysis.

title: Appendix C — Recommended Reading
text:
C.2 Microeconomics and Consumer Theory

Ahmad, Khurshid (ed.). Contemporary Practices of Islamic Financing Techniques. Jeddah: IRTI-IDB, 2002.

Overview of modern Islamic financial instruments and their applications.

El-Gamal, Mahmoud A. Islamic Finance: Law, Economics, and Practice. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2006.

Rigorous economic and legal analysis of Islamic finance mechanisms.

Iqbal, Zamir & Mirakhor, Abbas. An Introduction to Islamic Finance: Theory and Practice. Singapore: Wiley, 2011.

Comprehensive textbook on Islamic financial instruments and markets.

Siddiqui, Muhammad Nejatullah. Islamic Economic Thought. Lahore: Islamic Book Foundation, 1988.

Systematic presentation of Islamic economic theory and concepts.

title: Appendix C — Recommended Reading
text:
C.3 Money, Banking, and Finance

Ariff, Muhammad (ed.). Islamic Banking and Finance: New Perspectives on Profit-Sharing and Risk. Cheltenham: Edward Elgar, 2011.

Advanced analysis of profit-sharing mechanisms and risk management in Islamic finance.

Iqbal, Zamir. Zakah, Moderation and Aggregate Demand. IMF Staff Papers, Vol. 44, No. 4, 1997.

Macroeconomic analysis of zakat’s role in stabilization.

Jouaber-Snoussi, Karim & Abdelsalam, Omneya (eds.). Islamic Banking and Finance: New Challenges and Opportunities. London: Routledge, 2015.

Contemporary issues and future developments in Islamic banking.

Mirakhor, Abbas. Towards an Islamic Macroeconomic Model for Muslim Economies. The American Journal of Islamic Social Sciences, Vol. 8, 1991.

Framework for macroeconomic analysis in Islamic context.

title: Appendix C — Recommended Reading
text:
C.4 Waqf and Social Economics

Benthall, Jonathan & Bellion-Jourdan, Jérôme. The Charitable Crescent: A History of the World’s Muslimlands and Their Voluntary Sector. London: I.B. Tauris, 2003.

Historical perspective on Islamic charitable institutions and civil society.

Cizakca, Murat. A History of Philanthropic Foundations: The Islamic World from the Seventh Century to the Present. Istanbul: Boğaziçi University Press, 2000.

Comprehensive history of waqf and endowment institutions in Islamic civilization.

Kahf, Monzer. The Role of Waqf in Improving the Ummah. Paper presented to the International Seminar on Waqf as an Instrument of Social Development, 2003.

Analysis of waqf’s potential in contemporary Muslim societies.

Kuran, Timur. The Long Divergence: How Islamic Law Held Back the Middle East. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2011.

Critical perspective on institutional development and economic stagnation.

title: Appendix C — Recommended Reading

Asutay, Mehmet. Conceptualising and Operationalising Social Maslaha for Islamic Finance. ISRA International Journal of Islamic Finance, Vol. 4, No. 1, 2012.

Social welfare in Islamic finance framework.

Khan, Muhammad Akram & Mirakhor, Abbas (eds.). Islamic Economics and Finance. New York: Routledge, 2016.

Contemporary perspectives on Islamic economics and development.

Siddiqi, Muhammad Nejatullah. Muslim Economic Thinking: A Survey of Contemporary Literature. Leicester: Islamic Foundation, 1981.

Survey of contemporary Islamic economic thought and debates.

UNDP. Islamic Finance and Human Development Report. New York: United Nations Development Programme, various years.

Analysis of Islamic finance’s role in sustainable development and human progress.

Critical examination of contemporary challenges and debates in Islamic finance.

Analysis of economic challenges facing Islamic societies and potential solutions.

Political economy perspectives on Islamic finance development and regulation.
